title: Suffolk System
text:
The Suffolk System was the first <a href="Central%20bank">regulatory banking system</a> arrangement of remote <a href="Bank">banks</a> created in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. Starting in 1824, the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> of <a href="Boston">Boston</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, along with six other banks, created a system that required country (non-federal) banks to deposit reserve balances in one or more of the participating banks, which guaranteed that each country bank could redeem their <a href="banknotes">banknotes</a> in specie. The <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> became one of the most profitable in the country and continued to operate under the Suffolk System until 1858, when rival institutions complained of dictatorial practices and eventually national legislation banned state <a href="banknotes">banknotes</a>. The Suffolk System was the predecessor to modern banking practices and led to the creation of the <a href="Federal%20Reserve">Federal Reserve</a> that still operates today.
Background.
During pre-<a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> times in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, banks around the country issued <a href="bank%20notes">bank notes</a> as a form of <a href="currency">currency</a>. The large number of banks led to a large number of diverse <a href="bank%20notes">bank notes</a> that circulated around the country. Although many banks issued only enough bank notes that could be backed up by <a href="bullion%20coin">specie</a> (<a href="gold">gold</a> and <a href="silver">silver</a> during the time), riskier banks gave into temptation and issued more than they could cover. This practice caused many people to doubt the exact worth of certain notes and in turn have little faith in some banks. In 1819, the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> of <a href="Boston">Boston</a> was founded and only five years later it had developed the Suffolk System and recruited six other <a href="Boston">Boston</a> banks to join. The system was set up to ensure that banks could always back up their <a href="bank%20notes">bank notes</a> issued. This was accomplished by forcing all of the banks within the system to hold higher reserves of specie and keep deposits in the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a>, resulting in the first ever <a href="clearing%20house%20%28finance%29">clearing house</a> agreement for currencies in country banks.
Only a year later in 1825, all <a href="bank%20notes">bank notes</a> that passed through the Suffolk System were taken at par. In just a single year the Suffolk System had given these seven <a href="Boston">Boston</a> banks a uniform currency. As the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> grew in size it became able to assert pressure on other country banks and by 1838, over 300 banks (basically all of <a href="New%20England">New England</a>'s banks) redeemed their notes through the Suffolk System. All of New England now had a uniform currency. Throughout the system's existence, The <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> was sure to keep all of the country banks within the system honest by presenting banks with their notes and requesting <a href="bullion%20coin">specie</a>. The discipline enacted by the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> made virtually all <a href="bank%20notes">bank notes</a> in <a href="New%20England">New England</a> equal to their face value, allowing them to be traded within banks. The uniform currency was the first of its kind in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and remained in use all the way until 1858.
Purpose.
Economic historians still disagree on the original purpose of the Suffolk System. Although the system would later lead to stronger banking practices and a uniform currency for the Northeast, not all historians believe this was the System's original intention. Some believe the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> was not attempting to police the currency markets in <a href="Boston">Boston</a>, but rather to <a href="monopolize">monopolize</a> the brokerage of all the paper notes of the country banks in order to decrease circulation and open the markets for themselves. Although the systems’ initial intentions are unknown, its results are evident.
The Suffolk System in practice.
Throughout the existence of the Suffolk System many important banking practices were discovered and put into practice. After the system became in place, the role of <a href="counterfeiting">counterfeiting</a> in the New England area fell dramatically. Before the appearance of a uniform currency, many rural banks issued their own bank notes creating a large amount of different notes. This not only caused confusion, but also led many criminals to counterfeit bank notes creating an ever-present risk of accepting bank notes that may not be worth what they claimed.
The presence of bank panics during the existence of the Suffolk System also led to new banking practices that would continue in practice until present day. The <a href="Panic%20of%201837">Panic of 1837</a>, a <a href="deflationary">deflationary</a> backlash inducing <a href="depression%20%28economics%29">depression</a> and <a href="unemployment">unemployment</a>, was caused by many different factors including the practices of the <a href="Second%20Bank%20of%20the%20United%20States">Second Bank of the United States</a> and political failures. Although the country entered a <a href="recession">recession</a>, the activities of the <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> led the New England area to fare much better than the rest of the country. These practices included, lending reserves to other banks and keeping the payment system operating. Today central banks adopt these same practices that started with the private, commercial <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a>. More banking panics happened during the reign of the Suffolk System (Panic of 1839, Panic of 1857) but their practices continued to minimize the depression in New England.
The <a href="Suffolk%20Bank">Suffolk Bank</a> has been considered by some to be a <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a>, however it is highly contested due to its private nature. Some economist have argued that it can not be labeled a <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a> because of a lack of control of the <a href="money%20supply">money supply</a>, while others claim the system certainly had a degree of control or it would have been altogether ineffective. Although it seems <a href="The%20Suffolk%20Bank">The Suffolk Bank</a> cannot be considered completely private, it has proven that private individuals acting outside of political control are capable of providing the same functions of a <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a> at lower costs.
End of the Suffolk System.
Although the Suffolk System was a great regulator of unsound banking practices, it lacked the ability to properly administer the total volume of <a href="banknote">banknote</a> circulation. The Suffolk System regulated how many bank notes could be issued by country banks, but it was ineffective regulating the <a href="bank%20note">bank note</a> circulation of the system. It has been considered a "good regulator of a bad system". In 1858 the Suffolk System ended and was later replaced by the advent of the Bank of Mutual Redemption. The Suffolk System's many good qualities could no longer outweigh the lack of their ability to increase note circulation.
Although the Suffolk System was done away with by national legislation, the system of centralizing reserves among only a small number of banks developed into modem banking practice. The Suffolk System was responsible for creating strong banking techniques and in making smaller banks responsible for all of their <a href="banknotes">banknotes</a> issued. The system created a uniform currency throughout New England and most importantly the system help lead United States banking practices into what they are today.
